reviewText: I ordered this movie thinking it was a DVD only to find out it was VHS. Definately a movie I wanted to store in my collection but returned it without hesitation since I long ago got rid of my VHS player.
summary: I thought it was a DVD

reviewText: This is my favorite Jerry Lewis movie.I love the scenes where he's an Japanese cook,and he laughs like one.I also love the Tabletop dancing scene,where he grabs this woman's legs and says,Oh I like that! I also like When Mr.Loucaki's daughter asked him for a drink, he said a beer,and this Budweiser truck comes up with a team of horses,and the Budweiser theme plays in the background,while this man throws a case of Budweiser to Bo.

reviewText: Hardly Working was one Jerry Lewis movie no one ever heard of. I enjoyed the comedy that only he could do. The story was not much but seeing Lewis screw up every job he had was good. Being one of his later movies Jerry Lewis still shows he can make anyone laugh.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I admired Jerry's movies from the Paramount years from 1957 to 1965 and this movie from 1980 (not produced by Paramount) shows Jerry in his outrageous best! The misadventures of an unemployed clown seeking work from gas station attendant to the post office is FUNNY! Give it a look for yourself!!
summary: One of Jerry's best movies in his later years!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Despite its confessional parts and to be a cheap production this already bad appreciated, sometimes bitter, comedy is plenty of depurated comic situations with the calculated gag timing carachteristic in Lewis and in many points Lewis go a step upper taking the film to a higher grade of abstraction than his previous films . For instance, the previous scene to that in which we see Lewis disguised as a clown delivering the mail as reivindication of the importance of artist in society, and in which we inmediatly understand the repercusion of his menace against the pompous society who says to despite artists and the art of clowns, probaly the only subversive art that reminda nowadays, just in the moment he go out from the shot leaving alone his perplexed postman partner and a tremendous and reiterative noise is listened at time the images literally trembles. The film, for other part, is full of subtle visual narrative details and its structure so worked as his previous films as filmmaker.We have here a Lewis sharper than ever, revolted against a sort of critics and a public who have 'punished' this sensible and imaginative artist with false prejudices and ridiculous ' cliches ' ( and this is probably the part of the film that produces perplexity or confusion to whom watch the film the first time: commentaries that are, for other part, perfectly integrated in the story ) and so creative and funny as in his most acclaimed movies. By the way, don't miss the parody to John Travolta and his film " Saturday night fever " ( "Hardly working" is from 1979 )that is more than a funny gag: Lewis is again incisive with an industry that creates myths without consistence nor substance.An excellent movie with a very hard price
Title: N/A

reviewText: Though a surprise hit, "Hardly Working" (1981) remains among Jerry Lewis' lesser efforts. There are a few laughs, but Jerry's inventive cinematic style is nowhere to be seen.  It's a low-budget, poorly made film. The best thing  about "Hardly Working" is that it enabled Lewis to make the far-superior "Cracking Up" (1983).
Title: N/A
